choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome

questions.text: A 12 year old patient has Down's syndrome. He has over the past year become progressively more breathless, is losing weight and feeling lethargic. He is also becoming blue when running with the dog during walks. Which of the following cardiac lesions might be responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has Down's syndrome, which is strongly associated with endocardial cushion defects, leading to various septal defects.
  • The clinical presentation of progressive breathlessness, weight loss, lethargy, and developing cyanosis ("becoming blue when running") in a 12-year-old suggests a long-standing left-to-right shunt that has reversed due to pulmonary hypertension, characteristic of Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) with Eisenmenger syndrome (Option D) is the most appropriate answer. In VSD, a large, uncorrected shunt can lead to chronic pulmonary hypertension. Over time, pulmonary vascular resistance can increase, eventually exceeding systemic resistance, causing the shunt to reverse from left-to-right to right-to-left, resulting in cyanosis and severe symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atrial septal defect (Option A): An atrial septal defect (ASD) involves a defect in the atrial septum. While common in Down's syndrome, an isolated ASD typically causes a left-to-right shunt and usually leads to right heart overload without significant early cyanosis or Eisenmenger syndrome unless very late in life.

Transposition of Great Arteries (Option B): Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease where the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This causes severe cyanosis from birth and requires early intervention. The patient's presentation of progressive cyanosis at 12 years old is not typical of uncorrected TGA.

Tetralogy of Fallot's (Option C): Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by a VSD, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. Patients typically present with cyanosis and "tet spells" from early childhood. While it causes cyanosis, the progressive development of cyanosis in a 12-year-old with Down's syndrome, particularly given the strong association with endocardial cushion defects and potential for Eisenmenger physiology from a VSD, makes VSD with Eisenmenger syndrome a more fitting description for the progression of symptoms.

Key Takeaway:

In patients with Down's syndrome, who are prone to septal defects, progressive breathlessness and developing cyanosis in later childhood often indicate a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) complicated by Eisenmenger syndrome, where long-standing pulmonary hypertension leads to reversal of shunt flow from left-to-right to right-to-left.

questions.text: A 39 year old lady has a pulmonary systolic murmur which is louder on inspiration. The second heart sound is wide and fixed with splitting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic auscultatory finding of wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is highly characteristic of an Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) (Option C).
  • In ASD, a left-to-right shunt causes a continuous volume overload of the right ventricle, leading to prolonged right ventricular ejection and delayed pulmonary valve closure, which is unaffected by respiration, thus causing fixed splitting of S2.
  • A pulmonary systolic murmur that is louder on inspiration is consistent with increased flow across the pulmonary valve due to the left-to-right shunt in an ASD, with inspiration further increasing venous return to the right side of the heart.
  • ASD is the most common symptomatic congenital heart disease diagnosed in adults.
  • Other causes of wide and fixed splitting of S2 include Totally Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Explanation of Other Options:

Right bundle branch block (Option A): Right bundle branch block (RBBB) causes wide splitting of the second heart sound due to delayed right ventricular depolarization and contraction. However, the splitting is not fixed; it typically varies with respiration.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B): Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. Its auscultatory findings include a harsh ejection systolic murmur and often a single S2 due to severe pulmonary stenosis.

Aortic stenosis (Option D): Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh ejection systolic murmur heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids. Severe aortic stenosis can cause reversed splitting of the second heart sound, where the aortic component (A2) is delayed relative to the pulmonary component (P2), and the splitting narrows on inspiration.

Key Takeaway:

The hallmark auscultatory finding of an Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is a wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, accompanied by a pulmonary flow systolic murmur that may be louder on inspiration.

choices.text: A short systolic murmur at the right sternal edge
A systolic murmur maximal at the apex
A systolic murmur with thrill at the left sternal edge

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented for a routine check-up from the company. He was symptom free, but clinical examination suggested a small ventricular septal defect. Which one of the following findings was most likely to have been present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The question describes a symptom-free patient with a likely small ventricular septal defect (VSD).
  • A small VSD typically generates a pansystolic murmur at the left sternal border (LSB), often accompanied by a thrill (Option D). The murmur is usually loudest in small defects due to the high-velocity flow across a restrictive opening. While it can sometimes be heard at the apex, its maximal intensity is classically at the LSB.
  • The presence of a thrill further indicates a high-velocity jet, consistent with a small, restrictive defect.

Explanation of Other Options:

An early diastolic murmur (Option A): Early diastolic murmurs are typically associated with aortic or pulmonary regurgitation, reflecting backward flow through incompetent semilunar valves, and are not characteristic of a small VSD.

A short systolic murmur at the right sternal edge (Option B): A short systolic murmur at the right sternal edge is often heard in conditions like aortic stenosis, reflecting turbulent flow through the aortic valve. It is not a typical finding for a VSD, which has a pansystolic quality and is usually maximal at the LSB.

A systolic murmur maximal at the apex (Option C): A systolic murmur maximal at the apex is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, reflecting blood flowing backward into the left atrium during systole. This location and timing are not the primary findings for a small VSD.

Key Takeaway:

A small ventricular septal defect (VSD) classically presents with a pansystolic murmur that is maximal at the left sternal border and is often accompanied by a thrill, due to the high-velocity turbulent flow across the defect.

choices.text: ASD is the commonest cardiac malformation at birth
Congenital complete heart block is always associated with Anti-Ro antibodies in the mother
Ebstein's anomaly is associated with maternal exposure to lithium carbonate
Hypoplastic left heart syndrome is characterised by a large, dilated left ventricle

questions.text: Which of the following concerning congenital heart disease is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

  • Ebstein's anomaly (Option C) is a congenital heart defect characterized by the apical displacement of the septal and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve, leading to varying degrees of tricuspid regurgitation and atrialization of the right ventricle.
  • This anomaly is indeed associated with maternal exposure to lithium carbonate during the first trimester of pregnancy.

Explanation of Other Options:

ASD is the commonest cardiac malformation at birth (Option A): Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) is the most common cardiac malformation at birth, not Atrial Septal Defect (ASD).

Congenital complete heart block is always associated with Anti-Ro antibodies in the mother (Option B): While congenital complete heart block can be associated with maternal autoimmune diseases, particularly Anti-Ro antibodies, this association is not universal; in the vast majority of cases, the cause is unknown.

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome is characterised by a large, dilated left ventricle (Option D): Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is characterized by underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the left-sided cardiac structures, including the left ventricle, aorta, and aortic and mitral valves. The left ventricle is typically small and underdeveloped, not large and dilated.

Key Takeaway:

Ebstein's anomaly is a congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve that has a known association with maternal exposure to lithium carbonate during early pregnancy.

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital heart defect in Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) (Option B) is the most common congenital heart defect found in patients with Turner syndrome. A bicuspid aortic valve has only two leaflets instead of the usual three.
  • Patients with Turner syndrome (monosomy X, 45,X) often have a range of cardiovascular anomalies, with BAV being the most prevalent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atrial septal defect (Option A): An atrial septal defect (ASD) is a hole in the wall separating the two upper chambers of the heart. ASDs are common congenital heart defects, but not the most common specific defect associated with Turner syndrome.

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option C): Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a condition where the ductus arteriosus, a blood vessel connecting the aorta and pulmonary artery, fails to close after birth. While a common congenital heart defect, it is not the most common defect seen in Turner syndrome.

Coarctation of aorta (Option D): Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aorta, typically just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery. It is a common association with Turner syndrome and the second most common cardiac defect, but bicuspid aortic valve is more prevalent.

Key Takeaway:

The most common congenital heart defect observed in patients with Turner syndrome is a bicuspid aortic valve, followed by coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: A 39-year-old healthy woman has a faint systolic murmur on physical examination. An echocardiogram is performed, and she is found to have a bicuspid aortic valve. In explaining the meaning of this finding to her, the most appropriate statement is that?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV), which is the most common form of congenital heart disease in adults.
  • A key implication of BAV is its propensity to wear out and calcify prematurely with aging, leading to complications like aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation.
  • Therefore, the most appropriate statement explaining the meaning of this finding is that an aortic valve replacement is eventually likely to be required (Option A), often in the 5th or 6th decades of life, due to the progressive nature of the valve dysfunction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Other family members are not likely to have the same condition (Option B): Bicuspid aortic valve can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, and its prevalence among first-degree relatives of an affected individual is approximately 10%.

She should be treated with a cholesterol-lowering agent (Option C): Cholesterol-lowering agents are primarily used to manage dyslipidemia and reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. While general cardiovascular health is important, the presence of a bicuspid aortic valve itself does not necessitate cholesterol-lowering medication as its primary management.

Down syndrome is a common association of this condition (Option D): Bicuspid aortic valve is commonly associated with Turner syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

Patients with a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) are at increased risk for progressive valve dysfunction (stenosis or regurgitation) and calcification with age, making eventual aortic valve replacement a likely requirement. BAV can also have a familial predisposition and is commonly associated with Turner syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cyanotic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) (Option C) is a non-cyanotic congenital heart disease. In PDA, there is a persistent connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, leading to a left-to-right shunt after birth.
  • This shunting of oxygenated blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery typically does not cause cyanosis unless severe pulmonary hypertension develops later in life leading to shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome), which is not its primary characteristic.
  • Cyanotic congenital heart diseases:
    • Tetralogy of Fallot (most common)
    • Persistent truncus arteriosus
    • Transposition of great arteries(Option A ruled out)
    • Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
    • Tricuspid atresia (Option B ruled out)
    • Ebstein anomaly (Option D ruled out)
    • Eisenmenger syndrome
    • Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

Key Takeaway:

Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) is generally a non-cyanotic congenital heart disease because it involves a left-to-right shunt of oxygenated blood. In contrast, Transposition of Great Arteries, Tricuspid atresia, and Ebstein anomaly are all classified as cyanotic heart diseases.

questions.text: The 'snowma'' appearance of heart on chest xray is seen in which congenital heart disease:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The 'snowman' sign (also known as 'figure of 8' or 'supracardiac silhouette') on a chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding in Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) (Option A).
  • This appearance results from the dilated superior vena cava and the anomalous vertical vein draining the pulmonary veins, along with the enlarged right atrium and right ventricle, creating a silhouette resembling a snowman's head and body.
  • TAPVC is a cyanotic heart disease where all four pulmonary veins drain abnormally into the systemic venous circulation instead of the left atrium.
  • Eponymous chest X ray appearances in congenital heart disease
    • Snowman sign : Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
    • egg-on-a-string appearance: Transposition of great arteries (Option B ruled out)
    • Boot shaped heart : Fallot's tetralogy (Option C ruled out)
    • Scimitar sign : Partial anomalous pulmonary venous connection
    • Figure of 3 sign : Coarctation of aorta
    • Waterbottle sign : Ebstein anomaly (commonly described in pericardial effusion)(Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

The distinctive 'snowman' sign on a chest X-ray is a highly characteristic radiographic feature of Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC), reflecting the specific pattern of anomalous venous drainage and cardiac chamber enlargement

choices.text: He has coarctation of the aorta.
He is likely to have a loud continuous 'machinery' murmur below the left clavicle
He is likely to need urgent surgery.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is noted to have cyanosis of the lower limbs and clubbing of the toes but not the fingers. The blood pressure in the arm and lower limb is the same. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of cyanosis and clubbing of the toes but not the fingers (differential cyanosis), along with equal blood pressure in the arm and lower limb, is highly characteristic of a Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) with reversed shunt due to severe pulmonary hypertension, commonly referred to as Eisenmenger's syndrome (Option A).
  • In this scenario, the elevated pulmonary artery pressure causes the shunt across the PDA to reverse, leading to deoxygenated blood from the pulmonary artery entering the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery. This selectively delivers deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities, resulting in differential cyanosis. The equal blood pressures rule out significant coarctation.

Explanation of Other Options:

He has coarctation of the aorta (Option B): Coarctation of the aorta typically causes higher blood pressure in the arms compared to the legs and can present with radiofemoral delay, which is absent in this patient.

He is likely to have a loud continuous 'machinery' murmur below the left clavicle (Option C): A loud continuous 'machinery' murmur is the classic finding for a left-to-right shunting PDA. However, when the shunt reverses due to Eisenmenger's syndrome, the murmur often becomes softer and shorter, or may even disappear, due to the equalization of pressures and reduced flow velocity.

He is likely to need urgent surgery (Option D): Once Eisenmenger's syndrome has developed, surgery to close the PDA is associated with a very high mortality and is generally contraindicated, as the irreversible pulmonary vascular disease makes the patient dependent on the shunt for blood flow to the lungs.

Key Takeaway:

Differential cyanosis (cyanosis and clubbing of toes but not fingers) with equal arm and leg blood pressures is the classic presentation of a Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) with shunt reversal due to Eisenmenger's syndrome. Surgical intervention is typically contraindicated once Eisenmenger's syndrome is established.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Marfan syndrome is not typically associated with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, and its primary cardiac manifestations include mitral valve prolapse, aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, and aortic dissection.
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. It is associated with several other syndromes.
  • Syndromes associated with PDA:
    • Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18- ASD, VSD)(Option D ruled out)
    • Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13 - ASD, VSD)
    • Cri du chat syndrome (deletion of 5p)
    • Noonan syndrome (Pulmonary stenosis, HCM, ASD)(Option B ruled out)
    • Congenital rubella syndrome (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Noonan syndrome, Congenital rubella syndrome, and Edward syndrome are all associated with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Marfan syndrome is primarily characterized by abnormalities of the aorta and mitral valve, not PDA.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 22-year-old woman presents with a history of transient ischaemic attack involving weakness of right upper and lower limbs. She had returned to India from a holiday in the US two days previously. Clinical examination was unremarkable. An ECG, chest X-ray, CT brain scan and routine haematology and biochemistry were all normal. What is the most likely underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is a young, otherwise healthy 22-year-old woman who experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA). A crucial piece of information is her recent holiday involving travel from the US to India, suggesting prolonged immobility which increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
  • In such a scenario, a Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) (Option D) is the most likely underlying abnormality. A PFO can allow for paradoxical embolism, where a thrombus (clot) from the venous system (e.g., a DVT in the legs) crosses from the right atrium to the left atrium through the PFO, bypassing the pulmonary circulation, and then travels to the systemic circulation (e.g., cerebral arteries), causing a TIA or stroke.
  • Transoesophageal echocardiographyis the investigation of choice to investigate for a patent foramen ovale
  • The normal ECG, chest X-ray, CT brain scan, and routine labs support the idea of a structural cardiac issue allowing for paradoxical embolism rather than other common causes of TIA/stroke in older individuals.

Explanation of Other Options:

Atrial myxoma (Option A): An atrial myxoma is a benign cardiac tumor that can cause embolic events. However, it is a less common cause of TIA compared to paradoxical embolism via a PFO, especially in a young, otherwise healthy individual with recent prolonged travel.

Carotid artery stenosis (Option B): Carotid artery stenosis involves narrowing of the carotid arteries, typically due to atherosclerosis, which is a common cause of TIA/stroke in older individuals. Given the patient's young age and lack of cardiovascular risk factors, carotid artery stenosis is a highly unlikely underlying abnormality.

Embolus from paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (Option C): Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) can cause cardioembolic stroke/TIA due to clot formation in the left atrium. However, the patient's ECG was normal, making undiagnosed paroxysmal AF less likely as the immediate cause.

Key Takeaway:

In a young, otherwise healthy individual experiencing a TIA or stroke, especially following periods of prolonged immobility (e.g., long-haul travel), paradoxical embolism through a Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) is a highly suspected underlying abnormality.

choices.text: Squatting improve the cyanotic spells in children
Egg on side appearance in chest x-ray
Rastelli procedure is performed for surgical correction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The statement "Egg on side appearance in chest x-ray" (Option B) is not true regarding Tetralogy of Fallot. The classic chest X-ray appearance for Tetralogy of Fallot is a "boot-shaped heart" or "coeur en sabot". The "egg on side" appearance is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA).
  • Squatting improves cyanotic spells in children (Option A) is true. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which reduces the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD) in Tetralogy of Fallot, thereby improving oxygen saturation.
  • The Rastelli procedure is performed for surgical correction (Option C) of certain complex congenital heart defects, including some forms of Tetralogy of Fallot, particularly those with pulmonary atresia or complex pulmonary artery anatomy.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is associated with diminished pulmonary flow (Option D) is true. The pulmonary stenosis, one of the four components of Tetralogy of Fallot, restricts blood flow to the pulmonary artery, leading to diminished pulmonary blood flow.

Key Takeaway:

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a "boot-shaped heart" on chest X-ray, not an "egg on side" appearance. It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease and is associated with diminished pulmonary flow, with squatting serving as a compensatory mechanism during cyanotic spells.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not associated with patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The feature Bisferiens pulse (Option B) is not associated with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). A bisferiens pulse is characterized by a double-peaked systolic pulse and is typically found in conditions with combined aortic stenosis and regurgitation, or severe aortic regurgitation, but not PDA.

Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA):

  • Acyanotic congenital heart defect, a connection between the pulmonary trunk and descending aorta.
  • Associations: More common in premature babies, those born at high altitude, or with maternal rubella infection in the first trimester.
  • Presents with a left subclavicular thrill, a continuous 'machinery' murmur, a large volume/bounding/collapsing pulse, wide pulse pressure, and a heaving apex beat.
  • Continuous 'machinery' murmur (Option A) is a classic auscultatory finding of PDA, heard below the left clavicle.
  • A heaving apex beat (Option C) can be associated with PDA, particularly with a large shunt, due to left ventricular volume overload and hypertrophy.
  • Wide pulse pressure (Option D) is also a common feature of PDA, resulting from the runoff of blood from the aorta into the pulmonary artery during diastole, which lowers diastolic pressure while systolic pressure remains high or increases. Other findings in PDA include a large volume, bounding, collapsing pulse and a left subclavicular thrill.
  • Management: Indomethacin can close the connection in most cases. Prostaglandin E1 is used to keep the duct open if associated with another congenital heart defect amenable to surgery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Continuous 'machinery' murmur (Option A): This is a classic auscultatory finding of PDA, heard below the left clavicle.

Heaving apex beat (Option C): A heaving apex beat can be present in PDA due to left ventricular volume overload and hypertrophy.

Wide pulse pressure (Option D): Wide pulse pressure is a feature of PDA, resulting from the runoff of blood from the aorta into the pulmonary artery during diastole.

Key Takeaway:

While a continuous 'machinery' murmur, wide pulse pressure, and a heaving apex beat are characteristic features of Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), a bisferiens pulse is not associated with this condition.
